scenes.background: In a project team, colleague Alex prefers a direct work style, making quick decisions and taking action immediately. Colleague Lily, however, likes to carefully think things through and only make decisions after thorough discussions. During a project meeting, their differing work styles lead to a conflict. Previously, you proposed a combined approach that leverages both quick decisions and thorough discussions. Now, during the meeting, [Monica] and [Bob] further escalate the situation with their body language and comments. You encouraged the team to stay focused and motivated, but tension still lingers. [Monica] glares at [Bob] and says, 'This is why nothing ever gets done.' [Bob] retorts, 'Well, maybe if we didn't overthink everything...'
scenes.description: [Monica] glares at [Bob] and says, 'This is why nothing ever gets done.' [Bob] retorts, 'Well, maybe if we didn't overthink everything...'

options.text: Let's try to see things from each other's perspective and find common ground.
options.analysis: You encouraged mutual understanding and collaboration, showing strong emotional perception, self-regulation, empathy, and social skills.

options.text: Monica, Bob, let's focus on the task at hand and put aside personal differences for now.
options.analysis: You emphasized staying on task and managing emotions, demonstrating excellent self-regulation and motivation.

options.text: If we keep arguing, we'll never get anything done. Let's agree to disagree and move forward.
options.analysis: You aimed to de-escalate the conflict by encouraging compromise, showing good social skills and moderate emotional perception.
